message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Functional programming and input/output
Paper Abstract: A common attraction to functional programming is the ease with which proofs can be given of program properties. A common disappointment with functional programming is the difficulty of expressing input/output (I/O) while at the same time being able to verify programs. Here, the author shows how a theory of functional programming can be smoothly extended to admit both an operational semantics for functional I/O and verification of programs engaged in I/O. He obtains, for the first time, operational semantics for the three most widely implemented I/O mechanisms for lazy languages, and proves that the three are equivalent in expressive power. He also develops semantics for a form of monadic I/O and verifies a simple programming example. These theories of functional I/O are based on an entirely operational theory of functional programming, developed using Abramsky's applicative bisimulation. Graduate students and researchers will gain much from reading this book.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for "Operational semantics":

## Overview

Operational semantics describes how a valid program is interpreted as sequences of computational steps, and these sequences constitute the meaning of the program.(no content)Operational semantics interprets the execution of a program as a series of steps, each involving the transition from one state to another state.

## Key Approaches

There are several important approaches within operational semantics:

1. **Structural Operational Semantics (SOS)**: Structural operational semantics was introduced by Gordon Plotkin as a logical means to define operational semantics.(no content)SOS has gained great popularity and has become a de facto standard in defining operational semantics.

2. **Reduction Semantics**: Matthias Felleisen and Robert Hieb introduced reduction semantics.(no content)Reduction semantics are particularly useful given the ease by which evaluation contexts can model state or unusual control constructs, and have been used to model object-oriented languages, contract systems, exceptions, futures, call-by-need, and many other language features.

3. **Natural Semantics**: Big-step operational semantics was introduced under the name natural semantics by Gilles Kahn when presenting Mini-ML, a pure dialect of ML.

## Related Approaches

Other approaches to providing a formal semantics of programming languages include axiomatic semantics and denotational semantics.

Links: [{"title":"Operational semantics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operational_semantics"},{"title":"Category:Operational semantics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Operational_semantics"},{"title":"Denotational semantics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denotational_semantics"},{"title":"Axiomatic semantics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Axiomatic_semantics"},{"title":"Semantics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantics"},{"title":"Relevance logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relevance_logic"},{"title":"Refocusing (semantics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Refocusing_(semantics)"},{"title":"Stratification (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stratification_(mathematics)"},{"title":"Li Wei (computer scientist) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Li_Wei_(computer_scientist)"},{"title":"Semantic folding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_folding"}]

Here are the search results for "Operational semantics":

## Overview

Operational semantics describes how a valid program is interpreted as sequences of computational steps, and these sequences constitute the meaning of the program.(no content)Operational semantics interprets the execution of a program as a series of steps, each involving the transition from one state to another state.

## Key Approaches

There are several important approaches within operational semantics:

1. **Structural Operational Semantics (SOS)**: Structural operational semantics was introduced by Gordon Plotkin as a logical means to define operational semantics.(no content)SOS has gained great popularity and has become a de facto standard in defining operational semantics.

2. **Reduction Semantics**: Matthias Felleisen and Robert Hieb introduced reduction semantics.(no content)Reduction semantics are particularly useful given the ease by which evaluation contexts can model state or unusual control constructs, and have been used to model object-oriented languages, contract systems, exceptions, futures, call-by-need, and many other language features.

3. **Natural Semantics**: Big-step operational semantics was introduced under the name natural semantics by Gilles Kahn when presenting Mini-ML, a pure dialect of ML.

## Related Approaches

Other approaches to providing a formal semantics of programming languages include axiomatic semantics and denotational semantics.

I found comprehensive information about program verification. Here's what the search revealed:

## Overview

Software verification is a discipline of software engineering, programming languages, and theory of computation whose goal is to assure that software satisfies the expected requirements.

## Key Aspects

**Verification vs. Validation**: Verification asks "Are we building the product right?"; that is, does the software conform to its specifications? Software validation asks "Are we building the right product?"; that is, does the software do what the user really requires?

**Verification Methods**: The verification process consists of static/structural and dynamic/behavioral aspects. For example, for a software product one can inspect the source code (static) and run against specific test cases (dynamic).

## Formal Verification

Formal verification of software programs involves proving that a program satisfies a formal specification of its behavior.(no content)Subareas of formal verification include deductive verification, abstract interpretation, automated theorem proving, type systems, and lightweight formal methods.

## Applications

Formal verification can be helpful in proving the correctness of systems such as cryptographic protocols, combinational circuits, digital circuits with internal memory, and software. Prominent examples of verified software systems include the CompCert verified C compiler and the seL4 high-assurance operating system kernel.(no content)Formal verification is used by most or all leading hardware companies, but its use in the software industry is still languishing.

I've performed a web search for "Input/output computing." Here's what I found:

## Overview

In computing, input/output (I/O, i/o, or informally io or IO) is the communication between an information processing system, such as a computer, and the outside world, such as another computer system, peripherals, or a human operator.(no content)Inputs are the signals or data received by the system and outputs are the signals or data sent from it.

## I/O Devices

I/O devices are the pieces of hardware used by a human (or other system) to communicate with a computer. For instance, a keyboard or computer mouse is an input device for a computer, while monitors and printers are output devices. Additionally, devices for communication between computers, such as modems and network cards, typically perform both input and output operations.

## Technical Approaches

There are different methods for handling I/O operations in computer systems:

- A computer that uses memory-mapped I/O accesses hardware by reading and writing to specific memory locations, using the same assembly language instructions that computer would normally use to access memory.
- An alternative method is via instruction-based I/O which requires that a CPU have specialized instructions for I/O.

## Software Support

Most programming languages provide I/O facilities either as statements in the language or as functions in a standard library for the language.

Web search results for query: "Bisimulation"

Links: [{"title":"Bisimulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bisimulation"},{"title":"Probabilistic bisimulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probabilistic_bisimulation"},{"title":"Stutter bisimulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stutter_bisimulation"},{"title":"Talk:Bisimulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Bisimulation"},{"title":"David Park (computer scientist) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Park_(computer_scientist)"},{"title":"Guarded logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guarded_logic"},{"title":"Talk:Quasitransitive relation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Quasitransitive_relation"},{"title":"Scott A. Smolka - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_A._Smolka"},{"title":"π-calculus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pi-calculus"}]

## Bisimulation

In theoretical computer science, a bisimulation is a binary relation between state transition systems, associating systems that behave in the same way in that one system simulates the other and vice versa.(no content)Two systems are bisimilar if they match each other's moves, in which case each of the systems cannot be distinguished from the other by an observer.

### Key Characteristics

The set of bisimulations is closed under union; therefore, the bisimilarity relation is itself a bisimulation and is the unique largest bisimulation.(no content)The largest bisimulation—bisimilarity—is an equivalence relation.

### Intuitive Understanding

Bisimulation can be thought of in terms of a game between two players: attacker and defender, where the system is a bisimulation if and only if there exists a winning strategy for the defender.

### Practical Applications

Many people use bisimulation to reason about when two programs give the same results, and also to reason about security protocols, as it is a proof technique to show that two programs are bisimilar by finding a bisimulation.

### Extensions

There are several variants of bisimulation for specific contexts, including probabilistic bisimulation, an extension of the concept of bisimulation for fully probabilistic transition systems, and stutter bisimulation, which allows transitions to be matched to finite path fragments rather than single transitions.

The set of bisimulations is closed under union; therefore, the bisimilarity relation is itself a bisimulation and is the unique largest bisimulation.(no content)The largest bisimulation—bisimilarity—is an equivalence relation.

### Intuitive Understanding

Bisimulation can be thought of in terms of a game between two players: attacker and defender, where the system is a bisimulation if and only if there exists a winning strategy for the defender.

### Practical Applications

Many people use bisimulation to reason about when two programs give the same results, and also to reason about security protocols, as it is a proof technique to show that two programs are bisimilar by finding a bisimulation.

### Extensions

There are several variants of bisimulation for specific contexts, including probabilistic bisimulation, an extension of the concept of bisimulation for fully probabilistic transition systems, and stutter bisimulation, which allows transitions to be matched to finite path fragments rather than single transitions.

## Functional Programming Overview

Functional programming is a programming paradigm where programs are constructed by applying and composing functions.(no content)It is a declarative programming paradigm in which function definitions are trees of expressions that map values to other values, rather than a sequence of imperative statements which update the running state of the program.

### Key Features

In functional programming, functions are treated as first-class citizens, meaning that they can be bound to names (including local identifiers), passed as arguments, and returned from other functions, just as any other data type can.(no content)This allows programs to be written in a declarative and composable style, where small functions are combined in a modular manner.

### Pure Functions

Functional programming is sometimes treated as synonymous with purely functional programming, a subset of functional programming that treats all functions as deterministic mathematical functions, or pure functions. When a pure function is called with some given arguments, it will always return the same result, and cannot be affected by any mutable state or other side effects.

### Benefits

Proponents of purely functional programming claim that by restricting side effects, programs can have fewer bugs, be easier to debug and test, and be more suited to formal verification.

### History and Popular Languages

Functional programming has its roots in academia, evolving from the lambda calculus, a formal system of computation based only on functions.(no content)Functional programming has historically been less popular than imperative programming, but many functional languages are seeing use today in industry and education, including Common Lisp, Scheme, Clojure, Wolfram Language, Racket, Erlang, Elixir, OCaml, Haskell, and F#. Additionally, many other programming languages support programming in a functional style or have implemented features from functional programming, such as C++ (since C++11), C#, Kotlin, Perl, PHP, Python, Go, Rust, Raku, Scala, and Java (since Java 8).

Based on the search results, here's an overview of monad programming:

## What is a Monad?

In functional programming, monads are a way to structure computations as a sequence of steps, where each step not only produces a value but also some extra information about the computation, such as a potential failure, non-determinism, or side effect.

## Key Components

A monad consists of three parts: A type constructor M that builds up a monadic type, a type converter (often called unit or return) that embeds an object in the monad, and a combinator (typically called bind) that unwraps a monadic variable and inserts it into a monadic function/expression.

## Practical Applications

By reifying a specific kind of computation, a monad encapsulates the tedious details of that computational pattern in a declarative way, improving the code's clarity.(no content)Programmers typically use bind to chain monadic functions into a sequence, which has led some to describe monads as "programmable semicolons".(no content)One noteworthy use for monads is isolating side-effects, like input/output or mutable state, in otherwise purely functional code.

## Examples and Implementation

One example of a monad is the Maybe type, which forces the programmer to deal with potentially undefined results by explicitly defining two states: Just ⌑result⌑, or Nothing.(no content)At first, programming with monads was largely confined to Haskell and its derivatives, but as functional programming has influenced other paradigms, many languages have incorporated a monad pattern. Formulations now exist in Scheme, Perl, Python, Racket, Clojure, Scala, F#, and have also been considered for a new ML standard.

Links: [{"title":"Lazy evaluation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lazy_evaluation"},{"title":"Talk:Lazy evaluation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Lazy_evaluation"},{"title":"Evaluation strategy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evaluation_strategy"},{"title":"Lazy initialization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lazy_initialization"},{"title":"Functional programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_programming"},{"title":"Tak (function) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tak_(function)"},{"title":"Short-circuit evaluation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Short-circuit_evaluation"},{"title":"Haskell - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haskell"},{"title":"Evaluation (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evaluation_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Lazy systematic unit testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lazy_systematic_unit_testing"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about lazy evaluation:

## Definition

Lazy evaluation, or call-by-need, is an evaluation strategy which delays the evaluation of an expression until its value is needed (non-strict evaluation) and which avoids repeated evaluations (by the use of sharing).

## Key Characteristics

Strict evaluation always fully evaluates function arguments before invoking the function, while lazy evaluation does not evaluate function arguments unless their values are required to evaluate the function call itself.

## Benefits

Lazy evaluation offers several advantages:

- The ability to define potentially infinite data structures.
- The ability to define control flow structures as abstractions instead of primitives.
- Lazy evaluation is fundamental in big data frameworks such as Apache Spark, where computations on distributed datasets are delayed until results are explicitly needed, allowing for execution optimizations and reduction of unnecessary processing.

## Challenges

Lazy evaluation is difficult to combine with imperative features such as exception handling and input/output, because the order of operations becomes indeterminate.

## Usage in Programming Languages

Lazy evaluation is used by default in several pure functional languages, including Miranda, Clean, and Haskell. Additionally, Haskell is a well-known language that uses call-by-need evaluation, and because evaluation of expressions may happen arbitrarily far into a computation, Haskell supports only side effects (such as mutation) via the use of monads.

Lazy evaluation, or call-by-need, is an evaluation strategy which delays the evaluation of an expression until its value is needed (non-strict evaluation) and which avoids repeated evaluations (by the use of sharing).

## Key Characteristics

Strict evaluation always fully evaluates function arguments before invoking the function, while lazy evaluation does not evaluate function arguments unless their values are required to evaluate the function call itself.

## Benefits

Lazy evaluation offers several advantages:

- The ability to define potentially infinite data structures.
- The ability to define control flow structures as abstractions instead of primitives.
- Lazy evaluation is fundamental in big data frameworks such as Apache Spark, where computations on distributed datasets are delayed until results are explicitly needed, allowing for execution optimizations and reduction of unnecessary processing.

## Challenges

Lazy evaluation is difficult to combine with imperative features such as exception handling and input/output, because the order of operations becomes indeterminate.

## Usage in Programming Languages

Lazy evaluation is used by default in several pure functional languages, including Miranda, Clean, and Haskell. Additionally, Haskell is a well-known language that uses call-by-need evaluation, and because evaluation of expressions may happen arbitrarily far into a computation, Haskell supports only side effects (such as mutation) via the use of monads.

## Main Wikipedia Article on Input/Output

In computing, input/output (I/O) is the communication between an information processing system, such as a computer, and the outside world, such as another computer system, peripherals, or a human operator.(no content)Inputs are the signals or data received by the system and outputs are the signals or data sent from it.(no content)I/O devices are the pieces of hardware used by a human (or other system) to communicate with a computer. For instance, a keyboard or computer mouse is an input device for a computer, while monitors and printers are output devices.

## Related Wikipedia Articles Found

The search also returned several related Wikipedia articles covering specialized I/O topics:

- **Programmed I/O**: A method of data transmission between a central processing unit (CPU) and a peripheral device, such as a Parallel ATA storage device.

- **Asynchronous I/O**: A form of input/output processing that permits other processing to continue before the I/O operation has finished.

- **Channel I/O**: A high-performance input/output architecture that is implemented in various forms on a number of computer architectures, especially on mainframe computers.

- **General-purpose Input/Output (GPIO)**: An uncommitted digital signal pin on an integrated circuit or electronic circuit that can be used as an input or output, or both, and is controllable by software.

purpose: Extract transferable techniques and methodologies from research papers

message_text:
Excellent! The task is complete. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

The paper "Functional programming and input/output" proposes significant new theory and methods for functional programming. The author extends functional programming to include operational semantics for I/O while maintaining program verifiability.

**Key Technologies and Methodologies Extracted:**

1. **Functional Programming** (uses) - The foundational paradigm being extended
2. **Input/output** (proposes) - New I/O semantics for lazy languages
3. **Formal Verification** (proposes) - New verification methods for I/O programs
4. **Operational Semantics** (proposes) - Novel semantics for three I/O mechanisms
5. **Lazy Evaluation** (uses) - The context for which I/O mechanisms are developed
6. **Monad (functional programming)** (proposes) - Semantics for monadic I/O approach
7. **Bisimulation** (uses) - Theoretical foundation (Abramsky's applicative bisimulation)

All triples have been validated successfully with correct Wikipedia URLs and proper entity type classifications. The JSON file is ready for use.

Sources:
- [Functional programming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_programming)
- [Input/output](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input_output)
- [Formal verification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_verification)
- [Operational semantics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operational_semantics)
- [Lazy evaluation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lazy_evaluation)
- [Monad (functional programming)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monad_(functional_programming))
- [Bisimulation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bisimulation)
